conclusion: Introduction to the problem of determining the temperature at state C for an ideal gas.
V-T diagram showing three states (A, B, and C) of an ideal gas.
State A has coordinates (T₀, V₀) and pressure pₐ = p₀.
Line segment AB is parallel to the V-axis indicating constant temperature.
The extension of line BC passes through the origin O.
State C lies on the line from O through B.
Recall the ideal gas law PV = nRT.
For any point on the line from origin through C, the ratio of V/T is constant.
Since point C also lies on this line, V_C/T_C = k = 2V₀/T₀.
V-coordinate of point C appears to be less than V₀.
At point A, pₐ = p₀, Tₐ = T₀, Vₐ = V₀.
Using the ideal gas law: p₀V₀ = nRT₀.
For points on line OC, V/T = 2V₀/T₀, and if C has coordinates (T_C, V_C), then V_C/T_C = 2V₀/T₀.
Geometrically analyze point C, coordinates (T_C, V_C) = (T₀/2, V₀).
C is at temperature T_C = T₀/2.
The temperature at state C is T_C = T₀/2.
